• At-Home Learning Hub ​• Technology Resources • Technology Help Desk
• Health & Wellness Resources • Grief & Loss Resources

span.span: Dear
Distinctive Schools
Families –
At-Home Learning
is in full swing, and we want to see our students
every day
! Teachers are checking in with students daily, and keeping track of student needs — academic, social-emotional, and technological. We have a few updates, and some additional
At-Home Learning
resources for you!
We’ve compiled a guide for At-Home Remote Learning! Click

Don’t forget – we’re giving away a $150 Instacart gift card EACH WEEK! Log on at least three times each week and you will automatically be entered into the raffle. Winners will be announced each Monday. We can’t wait to send you grocery money – and to see you during At-Home Learning Time!

br.br: There are family resources for health and wellness, technology access, and links for the At-Home Learning hub on our website – visit the Updates Page for more information. As always, please reach out if you need anything at all. We are here for you, and #BetterTogether! ​

span.span: We miss you, and we want to see you! This week, we’re excited to launch an
INSTACART

Raffle! Log on at least three times each week and you will automatically be entered into the raffle. We’re giving away a $150 Instacart gift card EACH WEEK! Winners will be announced each Monday. We can’t wait to send you grocery money – and to see you during At-Home Learning Time!
We believe that we are
#BetterTogether
- we’re here for you, we want to engage with our families and provide opportunities to support you in any way that we can!
Do you need support? Can we help? Let us know:
Complete the
to help us identify the type of support you need:
Technology/Internet Assistance, Food Assistance, Medical Advice, Family Counseling resources or Mental Health support, and anything else you may need.

All relief efforts are intended to help offer guidance, support, and resources for Distinctive Schools students & families who have been impacted by COVID-19. A team of Distinctive Schools campus and network experts will respond to your inquiries as quickly as possible.
Dear Distinctive Schools Families,

We know that our communities are suffering the losses of beloved family and friends during the COVID-19 pandemic. We are devastated by these tragic losses and our thoughts and prayers are with the family and friends of our lost loved ones.

Despite our current school closure and required social distancing, we want to share some guidance and resources that you might find helpful if you are facing the loss of someone in your personal circle. Loss will likely raise many emotions, concerns and questions. Families are encouraged to share this information with their children if they feel comfortable.
P
lease find suggestions to guide your family discussion about this loss with your child below:
Talk about the loss of our community member with your child, this gives them permission to talk about it and ask any questions they may have that helps them understand the loss
Ask your child questions, about how they are feeling, to determine how they understand the loss of our community member and to gauge their emotional reactions to it
Listen patiently, keeping in mind each person will grieve and process death in his or her own way
Be prepared to discuss the loss repeatedly, children often ask more questions after having time to process
Only provide important, nondescript facts about what happened and at your child’s development level.
Acknowledge that it will take time to mourn and that this mourning process takes time

Please reach out to your child’s School Social Worker, School Director/School Principal or teacher if you need anything. We are determined that as a united front, our Distinctive Schools community will come together to help and support one another through this difficult time. Below are additional grief and loss resources to support you during this time.
How to Help a Grieving Child (courtesy of Bo’s Place © Do Not Duplicate Without Written Permission)
• Let the child know you are willing to talk with them about their loved one who has died. Allow the child to take the lead.
• Most children don’t want you to fix what hurts. (Thank Goodness, because death can’t be fixed.) They just need you to listen.
• Encourage the child to share stories and memories of their loved one. Ask questions.
• Allow the child to express thoughts and feelings related to the death of their loved one – whatever these may be!
• Listen
• Affirm the child’s feelings by letting them know you “get it!” Tell them their feelings make sense when someone we love dies.
• Take time to play with them. Children will move in and out of their grief. In between times they just want to be children. Let the child know it’s all right to be happy.
• Listen
• Use the given name of the person who has died. If possible, share your own memories of their loved one.
• Talk honestly with the child about the death.
• Listen
• Invite the child to be a part of the family grief process. Children are never too young to grieve and share in the family experience of the loss.

• It is not an adult’s responsibility to protect a child from the feelings of grief. It is however, gravely important for a loving adult to be fully present for that child in the midst of those difficult feelings.
• That’s Right, Listen!
• Honor the unique timetable and expression of each child’s grief. Just as each of our relationships is unique and special, so too is the expression of grief resulting from the death of a loved one.
• Remember grief is revisited throughout the lifespan of a child. Continue to support the child when grief resurfaces even after a long period of time.
Local resources:
CHI:

The Illinois Department of Human Services’ Mental Health Division has launched a free-of-charge emotional support text line, Call4Calm, for Illinois residents experiencing stress and mental health issues related to COVID-19. Individuals who would like to speak with a mental health professional can text “TALK” to 5-5-2-0-2-0, or for Spanish, “HABLAR” to the same number: 5-5-2-0-2-0. Individuals can also text 5-5-2-0-2-0, with key words such as “unemployment” or “food” or “shelter” and will receive information on how to navigate and access supports and services. Once a resident texts the hotline, they’ll receive a call from a counselor from a local community mental health center.

Individuals in crisis, including those considering suicide, are urged to contact the Disaster Distress Helpline 24/7 at 800-985-5990 or the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 24/7 at 1-800-273-8255.
MI:

The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has launched a statewide, peer-run warmline for Michiganders living with persistent mental health conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic. The warmline will operate seven days a week from 10 a.m. - 2 a.m. at 888-733-7753.

The warmline will connect individuals with certified peer support specialists who have lived experiences of behavioral health issues, trauma or personal crises, and are trained to support and empower callers. Individuals in crisis, including those considering suicide, are urged to contact the Disaster Distress Helpline 24/7 at 1-800-985-5990 or the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 24/7 at 1-800-273-8255.
Website Resources

will be providing mindfulness activities, meditation, and ways to help cope with and reduce stress and anxiety as a special bi-weekly program from now through May 2nd. Every Tuesday and Saturday at 10AM CST, anyone can join a FREE 20-30 minute virtual video meeting using this link:
. The call is limited to the first 100 participants, but all calls will be recorded and will be posted here as well as on Rainbows social media platforms.
- This organization offers information and support on grief. The organization is also running virtual support groups for grieving families.
- This page offers activities, articles, and videos for exploring grief with young children.
- 64 Children’s Books About Death and Grief -
This website lists sixty four different children’s books about grieving, ages ranging from 3-12.
- This website is peer health support community providing online chat rooms for people to talk about their grief.
- This website is an online community designed to connect those who are grieving based on background and similar experiences for chats and opportunities to meet in person.
- This organization “promotes awareness of the needs of children and teens grieving a death and provides education and resources for anyone who wants to support them." - NAGC Mission Statement
- This organization provides educational resources for those grieving the death of a loved one.
- The website
Option B
provides people with resources on grief and loss.
- Art activities for grieving children.
- Contains articles about death and grief and how to address them and help give children hope.

a.span: Helpful Children's Picture Books About Grief and Death

span.span: - This website has a list of picture books that help explain grief and death to children.
Articles and Educational Brochures

a.span: Understanding Grief in the age of the COVID-19 Pandemic

span.span: - Discussion of the different types of grief we may experience as a result of COVID-19.

a.span: How to Cope with Bereavement During the COVID-19 Pandemic

span.span: - Grieving the loss of a loved one may be especially challenging right now.

a.span: After a Loved One Dies - How Children Grieve

span.span: by David J. Schonfeld, M.D., and Marcia Quackenbusy, M.S., MFT, CHES

This guide is geared toward parents and family, but others who work with children may also find it useful. Teachers, coaches, childcare providers, and other caring adults can offer better support to a child who has lost a loved one when they understand more about how children grieve.

by MADD Canada. This informational article discusses the factors that can impact the grief process, and emphasizes the importance of talking about the deceased. Remembering loved ones and keeping their memory alive is helpful and healing. Many factors influence children’s views on death, such as age, religious beliefs, cultural and/or ethnic values, and their relationship to the deceased person. However, the reactions of their caregivers are of primary importance in determining how children will cope with death.

a.span: Saying Goodbye: Talking to Kids About Death

span.span: by Christina Frank from Parents Magazine - advice on how to talk to young children about death and grief and answers common questions they might have.
by Catherine Saint Louis from the NY Times - outlines the benefits of giving children the space and opportunity to grieve the loss of a loved one.

a.span: The Mistake I Made with My Grieving Friend

span.span: by Celeste Headlee - discusses the best approaches on how to respond to a grieving friend.

The Homeless Action Network of Detroit has helped create the Coordinated Assessment Model (CAM) Line. If you or someone you know is experiencing a housing crisis, you can call 313-484-4449 daily from 7am - 8:30pm. Click

for more information. Veterans looking for assistance, please call 313-576-1580 daily from 8am - 6pm. Additionally, the Housing Resource Center is available to help residents in Oakland and Macomb counties. If you are confronting a housing challenge, leave a message at 248-269-1335 or (toll-free) 1-866-282-3119 and a housing specialist will call you back for an intake screening.
Community Care Services provides outpatient mental health and substance use disorder treatment for children, teens, and adults in Southeastern Michigan online through

. Telehealth will connect you to treatment through your computer, tablet or smartphone. A phone call option is available for those without internet access. For telehealth assistance, or to schedule an intake appointment visit, Community Care Services at

The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has launched a statewide, peer-run warmline for Michiganders living with persistent mental health conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic. The warmline will operate seven days a week from 10 a.m. - 2 a.m. at 888-733-7753.

The warmline will connect individuals with certified peer support specialists who have lived experiences of behavioral health issues, trauma or personal crises, and are trained to support and empower callers. Individuals in crisis, including those considering suicide, are urged to contact the Disaster Distress Helpline 24/7 at 1-800-985-5990 or the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 24/7 at 1-800-273-8255.
Wayne Metro Community Action Agency offers assistance with energy & water, housing & food, children & family services, & job & education development. Call (313) 388-9799, email
, or chat with a Live Service Specialists weekdays from 9:00 AM - 4:30 PM on their website
National Domestic Abuse Hotline -
Advocates are available 24/7 at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) in more than 200 languages. All calls are free and confidential. The advocates offer the same support through their live chat services.
or click the "Chat Now" button on the website,
to start a chat. El chat en español está disponible de 12 p.m. a 6 p.m. Hora Central.

The Family Health Clinic is still offering wellness & mental health services. Services include medical services, prescription assistance, specialty care referral, mental & behavioral health, social services, health screenings & health education. You can call them at 313-670-9943 or visit
From Center for Disease Control and Prevention:

ul.li: Tips to keep children healthy while school’s out​

a.data-text: Resources for Michigan Families - Distinctive Schools

span.span: Dear Distinctive Schools families,

Next week, April 6-April 10, is Spring Break! While this break may not involve some of the plans we had originally scheduled, it does provide us with much needed time to rest, relax, and reflect on the past few weeks.
Spring Break:
We compiled
for students and families to use, if you’d like to over the break
Don’t miss our Spring Break Bingo!
While we will not be distributing meals over Spring Break, there are many options for you to pick up grab & go meals: see the

Distinctive Schools staff will be unavailable from April 6–April 10, 2020 for spring break. We are closing our digital doors, allowing us to rest, spend time with our families, and prepare for the next weeks of at-home learning!
If you need immediate assistance, please reach out to
. Your message will be returned as soon as possible.
On behalf of our entire team, we continue to wish safety and health for you and your loved ones. #BetterTogether

Dear Distinctive Schools Families,
​

br.font: Today, Thursday, April 2, Governor Whitmer announced there will be an extension to the “Stay home, stay safe” executive order. School buildings will remain closed through the end of the school year to reduce the potential spread of COVID-19, unless the ban is lifted. While the physical school buildings are closed, the state is calling for all districts to create and implement plans to continue learning for all students.

span.span: We appreciate your continued support with our at-home learning model. While we cannot physically be in the classroom,
teaching and learning is taking place every day

! As our students stay engaged and connected, we can submit data and documentation to ensure that these “at-home learning” days continue to count and will not need to be made up. We believe that learning is essential –no matter what – and in our commitment to equity, it is important that we ensure students do not fall behind in their grade level with exposure to content and learning.
​
There will be additional updates coming soon, we thank you for your continued patience. Please stay safe and healthy, and know we are here for you. Please reach out to
contact@distinctiveschools.org
with any questions.

a.data-text: <Update> School Closure & At-Home Learning Extension - Distinctive Schools

h2.a: Tech Distribution, Spring Break, Report Cards | 03.27.20

span.span: Dear Distinctive Schools Families,

We can not say enough how thankful we are for your communication and collaboration during this crisis. Whether you are braving the ever-evolving health issues as an essential worker, pushing your children to engage in learning despite the obstacles, or staying home to help stop potential spread, we are all doing our part to support each other during these uncertain times. Thank you!
We have several updates to share:
There will be ONE more opportunity to pick up technology.

ol.li: We will offer curbside pickup for technology and food. There will be no additional access to the building for any reason. Please note, this is the final opportunity to pick up tech, we do not anticipate distributing tech again.

Device replacement (broken or not working) will also be available at this time, but will only be honored if you bring in the original device, charger, and all parts for an exchange.
DCP Harper Woods families – pick up technology on Monday, March 30, from 10:00am–12:00pm during food distribution DCP Harper Woods.
PEC families – pick up technology on Monday, March 30, from 11:00am–12:00pm during food distribution at PEC.
DCP Redford families – pick up technology on Thursday, April 2, from 10:00am–12:00pm during food distribution at DCP Redford.

span.span: We are honoring spring break
, and will close our virtual doors on
Friday, April 3rd
at 1:00pm. We will be closed from April 6th through April 10th. During this time, we will still offer food distribution.
During break, students are able to log into programs on their own, and we will share an optional Spring Break Bingo enrichment activity for families.

Teachers will not be available during this break. We are asking all of our teachers and staff to disconnect and take time to be with their families and take care of themselves. Please do the same! Thank you for understanding.
Quarter 3 report cards
will not be distributed. This unprecedented crisis is causing us to
pause Quarter 3 for now,
until we get a sense of when we will be back in school and how we will finish the year. There will be no negative impact to your child(ren)’s grades.

We are giving particular care to the plan for students who will be enrolling in high school or for consideration to academic centers, to make sure none of our grading practices affect their options. We continue to monitor this situation and will reach out to families as soon as more information is made available to us.

br.br: In closing, we’d like to take another opportunity to thank our families for continuing to challenge your students to do their most important job as children – to learn. We are #BetterTogether, and we will get through this challenging time as a community.​

span.span: DCP HARPER WOODS ONLY:

em.span: We will now distribute meals on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays from 10:00am–12:00pm at DCP Harper Woods.

a.data-text: Tech Distribution, Spring Break, Report Cards | 03.27.20 - Distinctive Schools

span.span: MARCH 23, 2020
Dear Distinctive Schools families,

We hope everyone is doing well and staying healthy. Please know we are thinking about you and we are working hard to make sure our students continue learning and growing. Today, Governor Whitmer signed the “Stay Home, Stay Safe” Executive Order, directing all Michigan businesses and operations to temporarily suspend in-person operations that are not necessary to sustain or protect life. The order also directs Michiganders to stay in their homes unless they’re a part of that critical infrastructure workforce, engaged in an outdoor activity, or performing tasks necessary to the health and safety of themselves or their family, like going to the hospital or grocery store.
FOOD DISTRIBUTION:
Our campus buildings will continue to serve food on the days and times as follows:
DCP HARPER WOODS –
Grab & Go meals: Monday-Friday from 10:00am-12:00pm.
DCP REDFORD –
Grab & Go meals: Mondays and Thursdays, from 10:00am-12:00pm.
PEC -
Grab & Go meals: Mondays and Thursdays, from 11:00am-12:00pm
If you are in need of food, and cannot get to campus on a distribution day, visit
to find additional locations for food distribution across Detroit & Metro Detroit.

Our staff has done an incredible job of implementing at-home learning, while managing their own children's remote learning experiences and their personal needs. Our message to staff has, and will continue to be, that balance is our shared goal. We continue to promote healthy habits for all community members, and we must make sure our educators are taking breaks and connecting with their own families, while providing your children with valuable educational opportunities. We ask that you remain patient, collaborative, and communicative during this time period.
AT-HOME LEARNING – FRIDAY UPDATES:
Starting this Friday, our staff will have time to work together on Fridays to create and update At-Home Learning plans, and continue to plan for at-home instruction for the coming week.
Teachers will prepare students for
self-directed learning time
on Fridays; teachers will not be doing virtual check-ins with students on Fridays.
Students will continue to lead their self-directed at-home learning using resources that teachers and school leaders will share this week.
Thank you for your continued understanding! We are #BetterTogether.

br.br: Please stay safe and follow the guidelines shared by the CDC. If you have a moment to share any celebrations for the work our teachers are doing, we know it would be greatly appreciated. Sincere thanks for your partnership and collaboration! Please reach out to us if you need anything at all. We are here to support you. ​

a.data-text: <Updates> At-Home Learning & Food Distribution - Distinctive Schools

span.span: Dear Distinctive Schools Families –

We are writing with a few important updates. First, thank you for your responsiveness, collaboration, and communication over the past 72 hours. We have been overwhelmed by your compassion for one another and for our school community as a whole. We are #BetterTogether!
Based on recommendations from our local, district and state partners, and our own determination to proceed with the utmost caution for our staff, our school buildings will be closed as of

During this time, our buildings will undergo ongoing deep cleaning and sanitization. Following this deep clean, we will keep our doors closed until we are instructed to return to school. We will all remain available remotely to support our community.

We promise to continue frequent communication at the student, family, and campus level, as we respond to evolving recommendations and mandates from local, state, and national authorities. Should you need anything - please contact your principal or
contact@distinctiveschools.org.
Our leadership teams will be on call during regular school hours during this closure and should respond within 24 hours of an inquiry.

Our campus teachers and staff will continue supporting our students through our At-home learning approach. If you have questions, please reach out to your teachers or your school leaders. It is important to ensure our students continue their learning. We realize that students may be confused about this recent pandemic news and we are here for them. If you need any assistance talking with your child, please also reach out to your school leader. As you know, we will continue to have food pick up options in the parking lots of our school campuses and at partner schools.

Please continue to take care of yourself, your family and your loved ones. Throughout the week, we will share reminders and updates. Please be sure you are following your campus and our network on social media. Updates will be shared to
as well.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank our amazing teachers and staff. They have jumped in to support all of our students and they are doing an incredible job launching new and innovative approaches.

br.br: Thank you for your support, trust and partnership. ​

a.data-text: <Distinctive Schools Family COVID-19 Updates> - Distinctive Schools

font.br:
Distinctive Schools Families –
Below you will find details for campus hours Monday, March 16, and food logistics for your campus:

span.span: DCP HARPER WOODS:

As a reminder, our campus will be open during the following times for families to check out devices, and pick up learning packets or personal property: Monday, March 16th between 9:00am–12:00pm and 4:00pm-5:00pm, and Tuesday, March 17 from 7:30am–9:00am. Breakfast can be picked up during this time. Starting Wednesday, March 18, bagged lunch will be available on campus from 10:00am-12:00pm. Gleaners food pantry will be onsite at DCP Harper Woods on Monday, March 16 at 1:00PM.
DCP REDFORD:

As a reminder, our campus will be open during the following times for families to check out devices, and pick up learning packets or personal property: Monday, March 16th between 9:00am–12:00pm and 4:00pm-5:00pm, and Tuesday, March 17 from 7:30am–9:00am. Breakfast can be picked up during this time. Starting Wednesday, March 18, bagged lunch will be available on campus from 10:00am-12:00pm.
PEC:

As a reminder, our campus will be open during the following times for families to check out devices, and pick up learning packets or personal property: Monday, March 16th between 9:00am–12:00pm and 4:00pm-5:00pm, and Tuesday, March 17 from 7:30am–9:00am. Bagged lunches can be picked up at 11:00am-12:00pm Monday through Friday. Gleaners food pantry will be on site later this week, we will confirm details as soon as we have them.
